assessment.title: Introduction to Vital Functions and Body Systems

multiple_choice.body: Which of the following are vital functions of human life?

input.choice: exchange with the environment and structure, support and movement
the integumentary system and the skeletal system

response.feedback: Correct. These are two of the body's vital functions. Transport within the body and control and regulation are also vital functions.
Incorrect. Levels of organization are important in the study of anatomy and physiology, but are not independently a vital function.
Incorrect. Homeostasis and balance are important, but those terms refer to the result of vital functions, rather than to the functions themselves.
Incorrect. These are organ systems, not independent vital functions.

multiple_choice.body: Which organ systems are associated with homeostasis?

response.feedback: Incorrect. While these do contribute to homeostasis, they are not the only systems on this list that do.
Incorrect. While these do contribute to homeostasis, they are not the only systems on this list that do.
Incorrect. While these do contribute to homeostasis, they are not the only systems on this list that do.
Correct. Every organ system helps maintain homeostasis in some way.

multiple_choice.body: Which organ systems are most associated with structure and support?

response.feedback: Correct. These systems are mainly responsible for body structure.
Incorrect. These systems are involved in fluid transport and oxygenation of the blood.
Incorrect. These systems help with removal of waste.
Incorrect. These systems are involved with regulation and maintenance of the body’s water levels and pH.

content.p: Identify the primary vital function of each of the systems below.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the immune and lymphatic systems?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The immune and lymphatic system does not exchange with the environment, although immune components try to prevent pathogens from entering our tissues.
Correct. The lymphatic system returns fluid from the interstitial space and transports it to the vascular system.
Incorrect. This system does not provide structural support to the body.
Incorrect. Although much of immunity is controlled by this system, it is not considered a primary control system in regards to regulating functions of many body systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the skeletal system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The skeletal system does not participate in direct exchange with our environment.
Incorrect. The systems that transport fluids, contain a large portion of fluid, which the skeletal system does not.
Correct. Our bones provide the framework on which the rest of the body’s tissues are ultimately connected, although many of them indirectly.
Incorrect. The skeletal system does not play much role in regulating other body systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the integumentary system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. In fact, most of the integumentary system helps protect us from the environment.
Incorrect. The integumentary system includes skin, hair and nails, which do not transport fluids.
Correct. The integumentary system is very important for protecting us against our environment, especially the microorganisms that could cause infection.
Incorrect. Although the skin helps regulate what enters, or does not enter our tissues, it does not control the function of our other organ systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the nervous system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The nervous system can help control the systems that exchange with our environment, but the nervous system itself is well protected from our environment.
Incorrect. The nervous system contributes to the control of the cardiovascular system, which transports fluids, but it doesn’t have much of a direct role in such processes.
Incorrect. Although the nervous system itself is well protected from our environment, that is not its main role.

Correct. The nervous system regulates many other systems, such as aiding in the control of cardiac output (fluid transport), muscle movement (support and protection), breathing (exchange with the environment), etc.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the digestive system?

response.feedback: Correct. The digestive system takes in food from our environment and eliminates some wastes back into the environment.
Incorrect. Molecules absorbed from the digestive system move into the transport systems, but the digestive system does not directly participate in fluid transport.
Incorrect. This digestive system is made up of organs that are indirectly (through various connective tissues) connected to the systems that maintain structure of the body.
Incorrect. The digestive system does have some local control over its own functions, but it doesn’t have much control over other body systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the endocrine system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The endocrine system can aid in the control of systems that participate in exchange, but it does not contribute directly to this function.
Incorrect. The endocrine system can aid in the control of systems that participate in fluid transport, but it does not contribute directly to this function.
Incorrect. The endocrine system can help control the systems that provide structure and support, but it does not contribute directly to this function.
Correct. The endocrine system releases hormones from glands. These hormones then act as regulators of other body systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the muscular system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The muscular system can work with other systems (such as respiratory) to aid in exchange with the environment, but it does not do so directly.
Incorrect. The muscular system only indirectly contributes to this function, such as certain muscle contractions aiding flow through veins.
Correct. Along with the skeletal system, the muscular system provides the majority of structure to the body.
Incorrect. The muscular system can be an important “effector” of a control system, but does not have this as its primary role.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the respiratory system?

response.feedback: Correct. The respiratory system takes in air, from which we extract oxygen, and then exhales air that is higher in carbon dioxide.
Incorrect. The respiratory system works with fluid transport systems to deliver oxygen and remove carbon dioxide, but it does not participate directly in this transport.
Incorrect. The respiratory system plays little role in structure and support.
Incorrect. The respiratory system helps control blood oxygen and carbon dioxide levels, but does not directly control other body systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the urinary system?

response.feedback: Correct. The urinary system releases wastes to our environment.
Incorrect. The urinary system interacts with the main system for fluid transport, but does not have this as a primary function itself.
Incorrect. The urinary system does not provide structural support to the body.
Incorrect. Although the urinary system helps control the levels of molecules in our blood and extracellular fluids, it does not have direct control of the other systems.

multiple_choice.body: Which category best fits the cardiovascular system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The cardiovascular system works closely with the systems that exchange with the environment, but this is not a primary role of the cardiovascular system itself.
Correct. The cardiovascular system is responsible for our cardiac output, which is the amount of blood that flows through the body each minute.
Incorrect. The cardiovascular system does not have much of a role in determining the body’s structure.
Incorrect. The cardiovascular system can aid in the delivery of signaling molecules, such as hormones, but those are part of a different system.

content.p: In this next section, you will match the integration of several organ systems to a specific function. Choose the best answer from the choices given.

fill_in_the_blank.body: When the muscular, nervous and integumentary systems work together they can

input.choice: keep foreign organisms out of body systems

response.feedback: Correct. The nervous system can stimulate muscles that are attached to the skin of the face, leading to facial expressions.
Incorrect. The integumentary system does not contribute to obtaining nutrients, although the nervous and muscular systems do contribute to this function.
Incorrect. Waste excretion is typically performed by other systems.

Incorrect. Although the skin of the integumentary system contributes to vitamin D formation, which helps regulate calcium, the overall maintenance of calcium levels is primarily carried out by a different combination of systems.
Incorrect. The integumentary system plays in important role in keeping foreign organisms out of the body, but it doesn’t do so in combination with the nervous and muscular systems.

fill_in_the_blank.body: When the digestive, respiratory and cardiovascular systems work together they can

input.choice: keep foreign organisms out of body systems

response.feedback: Incorrect. Facial expression requires the muscular system, among others
Correct. Nutrients are generally obtained through the digestive system and oxygen through the respiratory system. The cardiovascular system delivers the nutrients to cells of the body.

Incorrect. Although the respiratory system can excrete carbon dioxide, and the digestive system excretes undigested compounds, this is not the best answer when considering the interrelationships between these three systems.
Incorrect. The respiratory system plays no role in calcium homeostasis.
Incorrect. In fact, the digestive and respiratory systems are considered “portals of entry” for microorganisms entering the body.

fill_in_the_blank.body: When the respiratory, digestive and urinary systems work together they can

input.choice: keep foreign organisms out of body systems

response.feedback: Incorrect. Facial expression requires the muscular system, among others.
Incorrect. The urinary system does not obtain nutrients for the body, although it plays an important role in helping retain nutrients so they are not lost in the urine.
Correct. The respiratory system excretes carbon dioxide, the digestive system excretes solid wastes and the urinary system excretes soluble wastes.
Incorrect. The respiratory system does not play a role in calcium homeostasis.
Incorrect. In fact, the digestive and respiratory systems are considered “portals of entry” for microorganisms entering the body.

fill_in_the_blank.body: When the endocrine, skeletal and urinary systems work together they can

input.choice: keep foreign organisms out of body systems

response.feedback: Incorrect. The skeletal system does not play a role in waste excretion.
Incorrect. None of these systems play a direct role in obtaining nutrients from the environment.
Incorrect. The skeletal and endocrine systems do not play direct roles in waste excretion.
Correct. The endocrine system releases hormones the interact with both bones and the kidneys to maintain plasma calcium levels.
Incorrect. Although the endocrine and skeletal systems contributes to immune cell development, the urinary system does not.

fill_in_the_blank.body: When the lymphatic, immune and integumentary systems work together they can

input.choice: keep foreign organisms out of body systems

response.feedback: Incorrect. Facial expression requires the muscular system, among others.
Incorrect. None of these systems play a direct role in obtaining nutrients from the environment.
Incorrect. None of these systems have excretion of wastes as their primary functions.

Incorrect. Although the skin of the integumentary system contributes to vitamin D formation, which helps regulate calcium, the overall maintenance of calcium levels is primarily carried out by a different combination of systems.
Correct. The skin helps keep microorganisms out of the body, while the lymphatic and immune systems identify and destroy microorganisms that have invaded the tissues.

fill_in_the_blank.body: Inferior is to superior as anterior is to

response.feedback: Correct. Inferior and superior are opposites; so are anterior and posterior.
Incorrect. Inferior and superior are opposites, but medial is the opposite of lateral, not anterior.
Incorrect. Inferior and superior are opposites, but deep is the opposite of superficial, not anterior.
Inferior and superior are opposites, but distal is the opposite of proximal, not anterior.

multiple_choice.body: In the abdomen, which direction is the digestive system to the integumentary system?

response.feedback: Correct. The digestive system is closer to the center of the body; and the integumentary system covers the body surface, therefore the integumentary system is superficial to the digestive system.
Incorrect. The integumentary system is the most superficial organ of the body, so the digestive system components cannot be superficial to the integumentary system.
Incorrect. The relationship between the digestive system organs and the integumentary system cannot adequately described through a lateral-medial relationship.
Incorrect. The relationship between the digestive system organs and the integumentary system cannot adequately described through a lateral-medial relationship.

multiple_choice.body: In the hands, which direction is the integumentary system to the muscular system?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The hands are distal to the other structures of the arm, but this does not describe the location of the integumentary system in relation to the muscular system.
Correct. The skin, hair and nails of the integumentary system are on the surface of the body,making them superficial to the underlying muscles.
Incorrect. The hands are distal to the other structures of the arm, not proximal. This does not describe the location of the integumentary system in relation to the muscular system.
Incorrect. Lateral means toward the side. The muscles are not to the side of the skin.

multiple_choice.body: Which directional term best describes the location of the kidneys with respect to the aorta?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Distal is typically used to describe the position of structures of the arms or legs in relation to the trunk, or in relation to a reference point of a structure. Neither of these apply here.
Incorrect. Anterior means toward the frontin reference to anatomical position. The kidneys are not in front of the aorta.
Incorrect. Posterior means toward the backin anatomical position. The kidneys are not in back of the aorta.
Correct. Lateral means toward the sidein anatomical position. The kidneys are found on each side of the aorta, making them lateral.

multiple_choice.body: Which direction is the brain from the heart?

response.feedback: Correct. Superior or cephalic means toward the head.
Incorrect. Anterior means toward the front; the answer for this question is a term that means toward the head.
Incorrect. Posterior means toward the rear; the answer for this question is a term that means toward the head.
Incorrect. Lateral means toward the side; the answer for this question is a term that means toward the head.

multiple_choice.body: As the blood in the cardiovascular system travels from the heart through the upper abdomen, and then from the abdomen to the feet, which combination of directional terms would best describe these movements of blood?

response.feedback: Correct. It travels inferior from the heart to the abdomen and leg and then distal through the leg away from the trunk.

Incorrect. Superior and proximal to the heart does not describe travel to the abdomen or legs as this would indicated flow first going toward the head, and then to a location near the reference point.
Incorrect. Anterior and lateral would indicated toward the chest wall from the heart and then to the sides of the body. This does not describe toward the abdomen and into the legs.
Incorrect. Medial means toward the center and superior means upward or toward the head.This does not describe flow toward the abdomen and into the leges.
